articles.headline: Sarbanes-Oxley, Bemoaned as a Burden, Is an Investor’s Ally
articles.snippet: Corporate chiefs are pushing Congress to repeal a provision on internal controls. But a study shows just how effective it has been.
articles.abstract: Corporate chiefs are pushing Congress to repeal a provision on internal controls. But a study shows just how effective it has been.
articles.lead_paragraph: Seismic accounting scandals like the ones that sank Enron and WorldCom in the early 2000s have, happily, been scarce in recent years. But they may well resurface if elements of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, the law created to curtail accounting fraud, are rolled back as some corporate executives are urging.

articles.headline: Equifax Hack Exposes Regulatory Gaps, Leaving Consumers Vulnerable
articles.snippet: Despite the wealth of sensitive information in their databases, credit bureaus don’t face the same kind of scrutiny and oversight that banks do.
articles.abstract: Despite the wealth of sensitive information in their databases, credit bureaus don’t face the same kind of scrutiny and oversight that banks do.
articles.lead_paragraph: Equifax warehouses the most intimate details of Americans’ financial lives, from the credit cards in their wallets to the size of their medical bills.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: Seriously, Equifax? This Is a Breach No One Should Get Away With
articles.snippet: Equifax’s main job is to collect and maintain data. Now the hacking at the credit agency uncovers a gaping flaw in regulation over data storage.
articles.abstract: Equifax’s main job is to collect and maintain data. Now the hacking at the credit agency uncovers a gaping flaw in regulation over data storage.
articles.lead_paragraph: Equifax, you had one job. Your only purpose as a corporation, the reason you were created and remain a going concern, is to collect and maintain people’s most private financial data.

articles.headline: We Lived Through a Flood. Now We Have a Very Long To-Do List.
articles.snippet: Harvey left a reporter and his family with a damaged home, ruined cars and a lot of worries. But navigating the adversity yielded some perspective.
articles.abstract: Harvey left a reporter and his family with a damaged home, ruined cars and a lot of worries. But navigating the adversity yielded some perspective.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLAIRE, Tex. — All I could do was reach for the towels.

articles.headline: Equifax’s Instructions Are Confusing. Here’s What to Do Now.
articles.snippet: You’ll need a credit freeze. You’ll need a fraud alert. And don’t expect Equifax to be much help.
articles.abstract: You’ll need a credit freeze. You’ll need a fraud alert. And don’t expect Equifax to be much help.
articles.lead_paragraph: It’s time for all of us to play defense, because Equifax clearly did not.

articles.headline: Apocalyptic Thoughts Amid Nature’s Chaos? You Could Be Forgiven
articles.snippet: Americans were excited about the eclipse, but hurricanes, wildfires, and an earthquake have some — and not just deeply religious people — thinking dark thoughts.
articles.abstract: Americans were excited about the eclipse, but hurricanes, wildfires, and an earthquake have some — and not just deeply religious people — thinking dark thoughts.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEWISTON, Fla. — Vicious hurricanes all in a row, one having swamped Houston and another about to buzz through Florida after ripping up the Caribbean.

articles.headline: Bridgewater’s Ray Dalio Spreads His Gospel of ‘Radical Transparency’
articles.snippet: Mr. Dalio has created an unusual and confrontational workplace at Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund firm. With a new book, he hopes to inject his ideas into the mainstream.
articles.abstract: Mr. Dalio has created an unusual and confrontational workplace at Bridgewater Associates, the world’s largest hedge fund firm. With a new book, he hopes to inject his ideas into the mainstream.
articles.lead_paragraph: As thousands of Egyptians took to the streets during the Arab Spring protests of 2011, Ray Dalio, a hedge fund billionaire, decided to sail the Nile River with some friends, including some other financiers.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: Mercurial Trump Rattles Republican Party Ahead of Midterms
articles.snippet: From siding with Democrats to inspiring Trump-like primary challengers, President Trump is shaking up the political environment ahead of the midterms.
articles.abstract: From siding with Democrats to inspiring Trump-like primary challengers, President Trump is shaking up the political environment ahead of the midterms.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s mercurial politics are already rattling Republicans heading into the 2018 midterm campaign, sparking Trump-like primary challenges in two high-profile Senate races and a host of lower-profile House contests, while pushing a growing number of moderate House members to the exits.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns

articles.headline: Hurricane Irma Barrels Toward U.S., Threatening to Engulf Florida
articles.snippet: The storm prompted the largest evacuation in Florida history, with people scrambling into crowded shelters and jamming highways.
articles.abstract: The storm prompted the largest evacuation in Florida history, with people scrambling into crowded shelters and jamming highways.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — This is an overview of Hurricane Irma, reported by journalists throughout the region. To see their latest dispatches from places hit by the storm, go to Saturday’s live Irma updates.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Can a Giant Science Fair Transform Kazakhstan’s Economy?
articles.snippet: With Expo 2017, the former Soviet Republic is trying to wean itself from oil and create a new global financial hub.
articles.abstract: With Expo 2017, the former Soviet Republic is trying to wean itself from oil and create a new global financial hub.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASTANA, Kazakhstan — By day, the huge and gleaming sphere looks like the spaceship of aliens who may not have come in peace. At night, it blinks out a playful pattern of colors and boosterish slogans on its high-tech outer skin — a few parts light show, a few parts bumper sticker.

articles.headline: The Prayer Circle: Texans Rebuild After Harvey as a Practice of Faith
articles.snippet: After the storm, 17 people joined in prayer before clearing out the flooded house of an aging widow. God, they insisted, was also there.
articles.abstract: After the storm, 17 people joined in prayer before clearing out the flooded house of an aging widow. God, they insisted, was also there.
articles.lead_paragraph: “In the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit …”

articles.headline: Bound to No Party, Trump Upends 150 Years of Two-Party Rule
articles.snippet: In many ways, Donald J. Trump has demonstrated a level of party independence even formidable figures like Theodore Roosevelt could not achieve.
articles.abstract: In many ways, Donald J. Trump has demonstrated a level of party independence even formidable figures like Theodore Roosevelt could not achieve.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Donald J. Trump set his sights on the presidency in the 2000 election, he pursued the nomination of the Reform Party, a home for disenchanted independents. “The Republican Party has just moved too far to the extreme right,” he explained. “The Democrats are too far to the left.”

articles.headline: Irma’s Fearsome Winds Reach Florida Shores, With Full Strike Yet to Come
articles.snippet: Florida opened dozens more shelters as the first wind and rainbands reached the state Saturday; more than 100,000 people were already without power.
articles.abstract: Florida opened dozens more shelters as the first wind and rainbands reached the state Saturday; more than 100,000 people were already without power.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Read the latest with Saturday’s live updates on Hurricane Irma.
articles.byline: By Marc Santora, Henry Fountain and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: How Is President Trump’s Business Doing? Check the Electoral College
articles.snippet: The red-blue political divide is not only informing the president’s policies, it is influencing the bottom line of the family-run Trump Organization.
articles.abstract: The red-blue political divide is not only informing the president’s policies, it is influencing the bottom line of the family-run Trump Organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOORESVILLE, N.C. — Business is booming here at the Trump National Golf Club.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Ben Protess and Andrew W. Lehren

articles.headline: Weather Channel Goes Into Overdrive Covering Back-to-Back Hurricanes
articles.snippet: In the network’s Atlanta newsroom, there is free pizza, lots of energy and scant mention of climate change.
articles.abstract: In the network’s Atlanta newsroom, there is free pizza, lots of energy and scant mention of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — At 8:06 on Friday morning, Nora Zimmett had a minor crisis on her hands.

articles.headline: At $1,000, Apple’s iPhone X Crosses a Pricing Threshold
articles.snippet: Apple will unveil a luxury iPhone on Tuesday that will feature innovations like facial recognition, but its price could be an issue in global markets.
articles.abstract: Apple will unveil a luxury iPhone on Tuesday that will feature innovations like facial recognition, but its price could be an issue in global markets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When Apple unveils its new top-of-the-line iPhone on Tuesday, it isn’t just expected to offer features like infrared facial recognition and wireless charging for the first time.

articles.headline: Where Trump’s Hands-Off Approach to Governing Does Not Apply
articles.snippet: Social conservatives are enjoying clout in Washington as they secure new policies on gays, guns and abortion. Some civil servants have left as a result.
articles.abstract: Social conservatives are enjoying clout in Washington as they secure new policies on gays, guns and abortion. Some civil servants have left as a result.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration opened the door to allowing more firearms on federal lands. It scrubbed references to “L.G.B.T.Q. youth” from the description of a federal program for victims of sex trafficking. And, on the advice of religious leaders, it eliminated funding to international groups that provide abortion.
articles.byline: By Ben Protess, Danielle Ivory and Steve Eder

articles.headline: As Amazon Pushes Forward With Robots, Workers Find New Roles
articles.snippet: Amazon is on the forefront of automation, finding new ways of getting robots to do the work once handled by human employees.
articles.abstract: Amazon is on the forefront of automation, finding new ways of getting robots to do the work once handled by human employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: FLORENCE, N.J. — Nissa Scott started working at the cavernous Amazon warehouse in southern New Jersey late last year, stacking plastic bins the size of small ottomans. It was not, she says, the most stimulating activity. And lifting the bins, which often weigh 25 pounds each, was also tiring over 10-hour shifts.

articles.headline: In the Future, Warehouse Robots Will Learn on Their Own
articles.snippet: At the University of California, Berkeley, robots are teaching themselves to grab objects they’ve never seen before.
articles.abstract: At the University of California, Berkeley, robots are teaching themselves to grab objects they’ve never seen before.
articles.lead_paragraph: BERKELEY, Calif. — The robot was perched over a bin filled with random objects, from a box of instant oatmeal to a small toy shark. This two-armed automaton did not recognize any of this stuff, but that did not matter. It reached into the pile and started picking things up, one after another after another.

articles.headline: Florida Is No Stranger to Hurricanes, but This Is Different
articles.snippet: As Hurricane Irma made landfall twice on Sunday and drove up the Gulf Coast, Floridians were left with hardly anywhere to hide.
articles.abstract: As Hurricane Irma made landfall twice on Sunday and drove up the Gulf Coast, Floridians were left with hardly anywhere to hide.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Bracing for hurricanes is almost a summer tradition here: the steady, clanking sound of wood banged to windows, the endless lines for bottled water and fuel, the pilgrimages to fortified shelters.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch and Jess Bidgood

articles.headline: Irma Roars In, and All of Florida Shakes and Shudders
articles.snippet: Hurricane Irma hit hardest at the Florida Keys and the Gulf Coast, but the whole state felt its wrath after one of the largest evacuations in American history.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Irma hit hardest at the Florida Keys and the Gulf Coast, but the whole state felt its wrath after one of the largest evacuations in American history.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Ready or not, Florida found itself face to face with Hurricane Irma’s galloping winds and rains on Sunday, as evacuees and holdouts alike marked uneasy time in homes and shelters from the Keys to the Panhandle, tap-tapping their nearly dead cellphones for news they were frantic to hear but helpless to change.
articles.byline: By Frances Robles, Lizette Alvarez and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Desperation Mounts in Caribbean Islands: ‘All the Food Is Gone’
articles.snippet: Food and water were in short supply on many islands in the Caribbean after Hurricane Irma, and witnesses spoke of a disintegration of law and order.
articles.abstract: Food and water were in short supply on many islands in the Caribbean after Hurricane Irma, and witnesses spoke of a disintegration of law and order.
articles.lead_paragraph: MARIGOT, St. Martin — At dawn, people began to gather, quietly planning for survival after Hurricane Irma.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed and Kirk Semple

articles.headline: Irma May Force Florida Insurers to Turn to Deeper Pockets
articles.snippet: Big insurers pulled back after Hurricane Andrew, leaving coverage largely to smaller companies leaning on a state fund and on reinsurance policies.
articles.abstract: Big insurers pulled back after Hurricane Andrew, leaving coverage largely to smaller companies leaning on a state fund and on reinsurance policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: With Hurricane Irma’s destructive force having pushed north, Floridians are beginning to check on what has become of their homes. They may also want to check on their insurers.

articles.headline: China’s Currency Rebounds as Economic Optimism Returns
articles.snippet: Though the country faces long-term problems, like soaring debt, the government’s recent moves have reassured investors that it can stave off crises.
articles.abstract: Though the country faces long-term problems, like soaring debt, the government’s recent moves have reassured investors that it can stave off crises.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — For those who worry about the state of the world economy, China has long been a major reason to lose sleep. Its financial system labors under a mountain of loans, while weaker growth has prompted many Chinese people and companies to move their money overseas in recent years.
